I have been here at least 3 times to dine in person. Hospitality was always excellent but service was always slow since they are always so packed. Either arrive before the rush or order take out.

I ordered togo from this Silverlake Ramen at LBX yesterday, 5/5/2020. (Cant help but wonder if I was the only one in long beach eating ramen on cinco de mayo ) but anyways, I ordered then basic tonkotsu ramen and I was immediately impressed. The soup of the ramen was subtle and flavorful. Not at all salty or oily. The veggies tasted delightfully fresh and the noodles tasted as tho they were cut and boiled to perfection. The piece of chasu on top was melt in your delicious. On a separate occasion, I ordered the pork bun. It was massive and delicious as well!  Needless to say, I'll definitely be back.
Hi Bianca, I’m thrilled to see that you enjoyed your meal.  Take care!
I have been here twice in the last two weeks and it is yummy. Great service and awesome food and high quality. My family and I love Silverlake Ramen, double thumbs up.
Thanks for your kind words!  Take care.

Eh, it's ok if you're craving ramen but feeling too lazy to drive to Irvine or Torrance for proper ramen.Ordered The Blaze, spicy with pork. Wow, it came out in a comically huge bowl. Looks like a giant lake of broth with a little island in the middle made of noodles and spinach. The presentation just looks sparse and weird. Speaking of weird, the spinach was unexpected. I can't recall ever seeing spinach at any other ramen place. It just didn't add anything to the dish. Just a soggy green thing floating in your bowl. And there was one piece of sea weed clinging to the side of the bowl, far away from the noodle island. Again, strange sparse presentation. The noodles were average. The pork was super tender and was braised or blow torched to give it a slight crust. The broth was "ok" at first. But towards the end, I grabbed a spoon and slurped it up. I noticed a strange aftertaste. Not very pleasant. Also ordered the chicken karaage bowl. When it arrived at my table, it was covered in so many things. Again, not what you'd find at a traditional ramen place. I'll admit the actual chicken was great. Meat was tender and had the right deep fried crispiness. But the rock-n-roll mayo and terriyaki sauce ruined it. I highly suggest ordering it with sauces on the side. Also comes with a shredded pickled daikon as a garnish. It's really tangy. I don't hate it, but I could do without it.So now let's talk about the weird workflow. You walk in. You see one person at the register, and you see these giant tablets on the wall where you can self-order and pay with card. You ask yourself.. if you know what you want and you want to pay by card, do you cut ahead of everyone else in the line and punch in your order? Or do you wait in line and wait til you're face to face to the tablet? Well, I observed people doing both. I saw some confusing faces, as well as angry faces from people waiting in line. This is just a terrible idea, especially since not everyone was eager to use the giant tablet, even though they were paying by card at the register.Next, after you order and pay, you wait for someone to seat you. During peak hours, this is even more terrible idea. Because sometimes people eat slow and it takes a while for an empty table to come up. But since you've already paid, you're stuck. You can't just bounce to some other places to eat if the wait is too long.Prices are on par with other ramen places. If you think it's expensive, then you need to stick to the 25 cent Top Ramen you get at the store. I think karaage bowl is a great deal. You get a good amount of chicken and rice for the price. It's a meal in itself.Overall, not a bad place but not my first first choice either. I might go back and try their other items. But I wasn't impressed with their Blaze ramen and the weird workflow.

Very hip, very modern, very cool. I like it. The menu has a great mix of fresh, fried, and flavorful soup options. My guy had the more lighter broth ramen made with chicken, I had the ground chicken and egg bowl and we also got the cucumber crab salad and karaage (I think). I'm actually not a ramen shop girl because I feel like it's always a bit rich plus a lotta carbs but this restaurant does an excellent job of providing non pork options. With this place you order first and sit down, I love that there's an option for both indoor and outdoor seating. The servers come around to collect dishes as you finish, as well as to refill your water glass.Also great that you have a view of the kitchen while they're making your food. This restaurant is located on the other side of Georgia's, across from wahoo's and the opposite side of panini kabob grill.
Thanks for sharing Carolyn!  Glad to hear you enjoyed it.

*Heavy sigh* I had high hopes for Silver lake Ramen, hearing all the great reviews of their other location. I came in after the lunch rush about 2:00pm, and browsed the Yelp reviews--a bit of a mixed bag regarding the ramen, so I tried to keep it safe and order the chicken karaage bowl, and the pork bun. The bowl was pretty bad, something was "off" about the white rice, and the chicken tasted like fast food chicken doused in aioli. I think I took two bites and tossed it out. The pork bun wasn't any better--now I may be comparing it a regular bao but the pork was under-cooked and extremely fatty (not sure if this is norm), but the flavors of the ingredients in the bun did not go well together, at least imho. Lastly, I was in the restaurant for about 5/10 min, but the fishy smell is intense! They may need to install some more ventilation--I cant imagine eating there for lunch and going back to work smelling like fish :(I love ramen, so I will be back to try it the ramen.

Probably one of the best broths for ramen that I've had thus far. There's a hint of roasted garlic in the tonkotsu broth that just completes it.You order and pay from kiosks in the front, then show your receipt to the host in the front who will seat you. There's a variety of seating options: the traditional table, high table, bar or patio seating. This makes it welcoming for parties of all sizes. We sat at the bar so we weren't hoarding a table from bigger parties. Maybe about a 15-minute wait for food at most, but that was because there were lots of take-out orders before us.We ordered a small karaage with spicy aioli sauce, the classic tonkotsu ramen and the blaze ramen. Like I said before--the broth was amazing! Noodles were firm and on the thinner side, and the chashu was a tender slab of pork belly that was to die for. For the blaze ramen, you had a choice of 3 levels of spiciness. At level 2, my boyfriend said it was still flavorful with a kick of heat. We highly recommend this place. Apparently there's another Silverlake Ramen in Silver Lake (yes, that was a "no, duh" moment for me). We just happened to stumble upon this location. There's plenty of parking in this mall and no wait when we came. Apparently the wait is ridiculous at the Silver Lake location, so just plan ahead.
The black garlic oil really does wonders!  I’m glad you had a wonderful experience here.  See you soon.

Decided to try a new ramen place. When first walking in, we were directed to the right to place our order. There is two options in ordering. You can either order on the touch screen or with the host. We opted to do the touch screen to see the set up. It was very easy to use however if you want to order quick and be sat quick then order with the host. About 3 parties after us ordered through the host and was sat before our order was submitted. We ordered a California roll and 2 Blaze Ramens with pork. The California roll was dry but the Blaze Ramen was good. We were pleasantly surprised that the pieces of pork were very thick and juicy. It was a bit salty but it went well with the broth. The noodles were on the thin side and were hotter bottom of the bowl.Flavor wise: The broth itself was creamy with a subtle flavor to it. For those who like spice, the spicy paste added a nice heat that wasn't overbearing. You can also control the amount of spice by choosing your option of mild, medium or hot. If you would like it spicier there is a jar of spicy paste on every table.Temperature wise: The broth was warm but could've been hotter and the egg was cold in the center. Atmosphere: The atmosphere was very clean, modern and there was good music playlist. The restaurant is small but it seemed more spacious due to the ceiling being elevated and the amount of windows. It has limited seating inside but they have a patio area to make up for it. The staff was not too attentive other than bringing our food, probably because it was slow. On the bright side, most of what we needed was on the table. They had good spoons and good quality chopsticks, which if always appreciated when eating a bowl of ramen. We ended up sitting in-between both of the doors since it was the only seating available inside which kind of sucked because we got air coming in from both ways. Price: The bowls were on the pricier side. We paid about $40 for 2 bowls and 1 California Roll. Every side extra cost about an extra $0.50-$1.50It wasn't a bad experience nor a good experience.

This place is located in that new shopping/eating center in Long Beach, right by the airport. My wife brought me here because we both love ramen. We were looking for a new ramen place too, since the one we used to frequent has dropped down in quality quite a bit. Not to mention, Silverlake Ramen has Tonkatsu brother that is deeper, richer, and tastier than any Tonkatsu Broth I've had so far here in the United States. By that, I mean to imply that I've also had Tokatsu ramen, at various other places, when I used to live in Michigan. The noodles are nice and thick, but not too thick. The egg is PERFECTLY cooked with the consistency being somewhere between soft boiled and medium boiled. I believe it has some kind of seasoning on it too, which is a nice touch. When I saw pictures of their Tokatsu on their Yelp listing, I got really excited because the broth looked really thick and milky/cloudy. That's usually a really good sign that the Tokatsu broth is REALLY tasty. Oh, and the pork is really lean, and less fatty than a lot of other ramen places I've tried.Anyway, 10/10, would have again!

Came on a Thursday night, 6pm ish in Jan. No wait...Minus:1. the weird way to order (millennial-ish kiosk) 2. weird way to get seated (no one really tells you how the order, seating is supposed to work).3. Lack of "service"-no one really greets you after you sit, they just look at your receipt, drop your ramen bowl off.. then you are left alone unless you flag someone down for whatever your need.Parking: easy tons a lbx. Park by the tj max side.. easy/out.I really liked my ramen and gyoza! Edamame pass... micowave tasting beans and minimal salt..meh (you should do spicy garlic edamame!!I got:-the shoyu on fire level 2 spice with pork bellyThis was sooo delish! Clean broth, lots of umami.  The roasted jalapeno, fresh geen onion, slab o meat, corn kernels all worked well.-great ratio noodles to broth (you can order more noodles on the side if you like stuffing your face with more carbs).-noodles were perfect.  Bit of chewy.. not soggy.-the fire level was perfect.  Keeps the hot in you mouth without worrying about gonna come out the other end the next day.We sat at the small kitchen counter watching the ramen cooking craze.Its a small space.  Maybe sits 50ish people max, less tables more community seating.They seem to do a TON of take outs which is maybe why the in  house service folks are distracted.We'd come back.  Hope they work on their customer service a bit... would have given 5 stars of so.

Based on the name of this place, I had a feeling Silverlake Ramen would have vegan options. Luckily their menu clearly states what is vegetarian and they also provide an allergen menu online so I can further research what is plant-based.The Veggie Ramen has tasty miso-based broth! I like that the presentation is very green due to the broccolini, baby greens, kale, and avocado. This is the first time I've had avocado in ramen. Not sure how I feel about that but I also won't kick it out of bed. There's also tofu, corn, and bean sprouts. Though you can't see it in my photo, there are mushrooms hidden under all those toppings. This dish is very noodle heavy which might hit the spot for some people. But I might ask if I can get half the amount of noodles next time. The day we came here, it was a particularly cold December evening so this soup totally hit the spot! bit.ly/2QxjVI3The Mabo Tofu Bowl was quite yummy as well. It is a bit different from other mapo tofu dishes I've had. Usually, I have the sauce mixed in with the tofu. This version has the sauce on top of the tofu. I loved the eggplant! The ginger was a nice addition and I love that it was topped with fresh green onions. I hoped that they had brown rice as an option but unfortunately they don't have it. But I'm hoping they might consider offering it in the future. bit.ly/2QOHmeMThe two times we've been here, they had a cashier taking orders. It makes me wonder why they have the self-service touch screens? I prefer customer service from a real person anyway. And they're friendly and helpful here too. Also, purse hooks at the bar-height tables!Plenty of free parking at LBX including charging stations for our Tesla :)

Wow! What a delicious and efficient ramen spot! I stopped by to have lunch here and it was everything I could have wanted. You order upon entry so it's quick-- no need to wait for a server or anything and your food comes out within minutes.I order the Classic ramen with pork belly and I could not get enough. The soup was the perfect amount of creamy and the egg was smooth and cooked just right. (My mouth is seriously watering as I write this). The portions are also super generousThe servers are patient and attentive and while parking can be tough, it is very worth the stop. I can't wait to dine her again!**they take Apple Pay which is perfect if you forget your wallet

I came here on a Monday lunch and we didn't have to wait. You order at the kiosk or the cashier and proceed to find your own seat. We got the classic and the blaze ramen, the latter apparently being their best seller. You can pick the meat (we picked pork on both). We also ordered a pork bun on the side.The food comes out fairly quick. The broth is very creamy and thick - really rich ramen. The bowls have decent servings of noodles and soup and a thick cut of pork.I think that the classic and blaze have the same base but the blaze with the spice takes it to another level, so I would recommend this. The bun was ok - pork was excellent but I wasn't feeling the mayo.Overall not bad - I would like to try their gyoza or rice bowls next time just to try.Perhaps between 2 people one ramen and the others on the side would be enough, as I wasn't able to finish my ramen.Then again, it was lunch and i don't normally eat a lot for lunch.

Supah creamyyyy ramen and pork CHOP belly like at an American steakhouse. They're huge! Friend got the tsukemen, got 3 meats, which was Overkill, but he gave me 1 of them for The Blaze that I got which only had 1, and that's not cool.Geeeeet the black garlic oil with the classic blaze! Try half without, then finish the second half with the oil, A WHOLE DIFF SOUP.The crispy rice appetizer is like eating Hashbrowns! Supah solid. Fun to take a few bites into it. Mushrooms with the salad are solid. Decent portion, nice vinagrette. Feels like modern take on a ramen restaurant, down to the food choices, vibe, and logistics of it.

I ate at the original Silverlake Ramen in Silverlake a few years ago, and loved their Veggie Ramen. I recall it being rich, flavorful, and creamy. The company has since rapidly expanded, and when this new location popped up in Long Beach, I was excited to try them again. We ordered delivery via Postmates, since we are out of their delivery range-they are located near the airport. This time, the Veggie Ramen was barely edible. The grayish broth was completely flavorless, and the weird assortment of veggies (broccolini, corn, huge chunks of undercooked soft tofu, avocado (?!)) had a bitter aftertaste. I love avocado as much as the next Californian, but it has no place in ramen. The noodles were okay, albeit not fresh. My boyfriend got the Shoyu Ramen and was equally underwhelmed. We also got the Seaweed Salad, which was too sweet and drowning in dressing, and the Spicy Tuna Bowl, which my boyfriend enjoyed. Overall, a really disappointing meal. Avoid.

One taste of the spicy, creamy tonkotsu broth and I knew... my experience was going to be extraordinary.At Silverlake, the ramen is prepared fresh and articulate. Generous toppings are given, great portion sizes are delivered, and flavors tend to soak me into moments where my tastebuds seemed to have a fun time exploring this new and creative flavor. The broth is Oh, So Creamy!-- the creamiest ever... and that was why Silverlake's experience was so unique.Truly great!
Hi Desiree,I’m very happy to hear about your experience!  Hope to see you again soon.  Take care.

Silverlake Ramen was one of my favorite restaurants to go to when I moved to LB for college. I've dined in quite often to get my ramen fix with friends and I have only great experiences here! I always order the Blaze ramen because it's so good and gives the right amount of kick. The noodles here are light and chewy. The broth is super creamy and tastes amazing. One thing I found really interesting was the way you order before being seated. It doesn't seem to pose a problem for me so I just go with the flow. Be careful though because wait times here can get pretty insane. Otherwise, it's a great place to grab a fulfilling, warm bowl of ramen in the LB area (:

So much hype around Silverlake Ramen and now I don't have to drive too far!Parking wasn't terrible as the shopping area is large. Location is a decent size and had a very open vibe. You enter and order at the kiosk or with the cashier and they help you find a seat. Waiters were friendly but it did take some time to flag a couple down since it was busy. Not their fault though.Ramen was a solid 7/10! The broth was great and tasty, just wish I had a tad more noodles

The arguable king in Ramen on the eastside of Los Angeles arrives in Long Beach. Much like Pizza, Pho, and Sushi, many will judge you based on your favorites and although I am hesitant to commit to a single favorite - on Yelp anyway - nearly half of Los Angeles would swear by Silverlake Ramen which is unlikely due to its location on Sunset Boulevard. I mean, you shouldn't be able to find a real deal bowl of Ramen on Sunset of all places, right? Wrong. Well, Silverlake Ramen has done so well for itself it is expanding with a new spot in Long Beach and another on the way for Irvine in The Spectrum. The Long Beach location is in the center of The Hangar, a newly developed (and extremely trendy) area featuring a massive food hall and boutique-style stores near the Long Beach Airport or the "LGB" if you are a local. The interior is modern, sleek, and a little funky as far as a modern Ramen joint goes but the ordering procedure is... well... straight-up wack thanks to the single ordering kiosk being employed, the weird way they assign you to a table, and the line back up this creates. The only plus about this strange fast-casual format is that tips are unnecessary. As for the Ramen itself? I thought you'd never ask. I naturally ordered the celebrated Tonkatsu Ramen. The presentation of the Ramen is quite noble. The portions include an adequate amount of food to serve a single starving person or two reasonably hungry people (perhaps 3?). The pork broth takes 16 hours to render which makes it both intense and savory, with the rich essences erupting at the first spoonful. The Chashu is laid over the Noodles and a bed of Green Onions, which were cleverly glazed on the edges. The Chashu dissolved in the mouth and implemented the ideal amount of saltiness.The Bean Sprouts provided a crunchiness that juxtaposes itself flawlessly with the smoothness of the Noodles. It is merited to mention that a single bowl is remarkably filling, with multiple customers taking to-go bowls home on my visit. For a mere $13.00 after-tax, it is a deal that cannot be missed. I was highly impressed with Silverlake Ramen and cannot wait for a return stop. They clearly have found significant investment capital as this is not the only outpost they are opening - expect to see new locations soon in Huntington Beach, Irvine, Cerritos, Oxnard, and Koreatown. Ramen lovers rejoice!

Expensive for ramen but quite substantial. The Classic Tonkotsu and the Blaze are both super rich. If the broths were any thicker, they'd be tsukemen broth. In fact, the two items are so similar that I suspect the only difference is the chili paste in the Blaze. I love that they use spinach in the ramen. It's not common to find actual green vegetable in ramen and the spinach was a great addition to the creamy broth. I also love the thick chasu pork. It's fatty and tender and super satisfying to bite into. Although there is technically only one slice of chashu, I couldn't actually finish it in one sitting and had to take it home.

When you think of Ramen, the Long Beach area usually doesn't come to mind. Well, a few spots have opened up and Silverlake is one of them. If you hadn't heard of the Long Beach Exchange - it's a new addition to the food scene in the Long Beach area. Silverlake Ramen isn't located in the Hangar, but as one of the shops next to Georgia's, facing Ulta and Old Navy. Lots of parking. At least that's what my friend and I found when we stopped in for a very late lunch one weekday. I don't know how packed the lot gets during lunch hour or on the weekends however, we drove up, and right into a spot. Walked in, ordered and sat down. No wait. The experience started off well and only got better from there. I ordered the Spicy Tonkotsu and a Chicken Karaage. I know it's like a broken record when I say it wasn't spicy, but it wasn't. However, the broth wasn't bland or too oily and for my taste, didn't need much in the way of condiments for flavor. The noodles were done al dente, as I prefer. As for the chicken, I liked the juicy meat however, the skin was a little too done for me. Not sure if that makes sense however, it seemed like it was bathed in oil too long and for me the outer layer had an oily taste. The dipping sauce which comes with the order took care of that taste for me - otherwise I might have considered sending it back. The service was friendly and efficient. Attentive not so much as not much was needed. Someone took our order. Someone brought our utensils and water. Then someone brought our order to the table. Not much follow up was needed as the bill was already paid and we were close enough to the water dispenser for refills. I had a pleasant experience. The only feedback I have is that the music volume was a little too loud. Most of the visit, I had difficulty hearing my friend speak.

Yay a good RAMEN place in LB!Located directly behind Georgia's, Silverlake Ramen brings the ramen fire! You walk in and make a right to the register to order and pay. You can choose to tip at this time or leave a tip on your table before you leave. They give you a number and wait for your ramen to be served to you. There is outdoor seating as well as heaters. This was my first time eating here and the service was pretty good. The servers bring your drinks to your table. Onto the ramen, I got the shoyu with the pork belly. It was so good. The pork belly piece was so thick and tender. It was a good portion and I didn't even finish it. The noodles were standard and the broth was tasty. The broth could be a little hotter (temperature wise) in my opinion. But otherwise it was good. Parking isn't an issue and it shares the lot with other businesses. I'll probably come back and try the tonkotsu and e karaage!

Got my ramen delivered but I've been hearing so much about this place. I chose the blaze- a spicy tonkatsu ramen and it was delicious! The ramen broth was so tasty. For my protein I choose chicken. I've never had chicken in my ramen unless get it without protein. The texture didn't sit right with me so I took it out. After that, everything was superb. I appreciate the presentation and the prices were average for a joint at the hanger.

Ambiance: the set-up is totally bad!!! They only have one register open.Very chilled with an average noise level inside as for the outside it's too cramped and one of the table is blocking the exit way. Food: Pork bun is a must, the pork belly is so soft and the Saunders with the bun went well together. Crispy chicken karaage was not crispy at all, it's not what a karaage is usually is (you'll see in the picture). The chicken itself is lightly breaded so it's more like on a healthy side so they should rename it to something else. The Shoyu was good, the chicken was tender and soft enough to chew on, the broth was delicious. The Blaze ramen was okay, the broth was a little too thick for me and the pork belly that came with it was very hard and hard to chew I would have expected to be soft like the pork bun but I was really disappointed. Service: They were lagging because they were having a receipt print out problem and it took them a while till we can finally order, wished they offered a free drink after eating for nearly 10min until our order was place. The waiter did follow up once we were seated but it took them forever for my pork bun or the katrsge and our ramen came first/

I was more than excited hearing that a Silverlake Ramen was opening in Long Beach! I love going to and trying new Ramen places but Silverlake will always be one of my staple favorites to go to. I got the spicy tonkotsu, the blaze. First off, the broth was very rich and flavorful with just the right amount of kick from the spice. The noodles were well cooked, had a good texture and was accompanied by pork that was very tender. Every time I come here, it is always packed with people, but in my opinion, the food is worth the wait.

Not too much a fan of ramen, but my brother is a ramen connoisseur and took me here since it was new and close to home. Gotta say, the ramen was fine (again, I'm not a huge fan). My mom, dad, aunt enjoyed it so no complaints. If you're looking for a hot bowl of soup, this place will do. ^_^By the way. They use the new type of touch ordering system and then make you wait before you sit down. I'm not a fan of the new trend in touch ordering , but oh well.

My friends & I were so happy to hear about this spot opening up! It's located at LBX, near other restaurants. Parking isn't bad. We came on a Sunday afternoon & surprisingly it wasn't as busy as I expected for a grand opening. When you walk in, you order first then find a seat. It's not bad, but going in with a fairly big group, it might be hard to find seats together. They do have outside seating though and their tables are pretty close to each other both in and outside. They also have bar seating a high table seating with seats on one side. Their service is great too!It took maybe like 15-20 minutes for our food to come out. I ordered the classic tonkotsu and my boyfriend ordered the blaze one. My other friends ordered the same as us. I was honestly expecting a lot since I loved it when I went to the LA location. However, I was underwhelmed.. The broth wasn't as rich and flavorful. The meat was a little chewy and dry for me. They also forgot to add meat to one of the orders. We were a bit surprised by that lol. The noodles were good and chewy though! The egg was fine, but wish it was more of a soft boiled egg. Maybe it wasn't as great since it was still their opening weekend. But definitely will give it another visit in the future.
Thank you for your review.  I will bring this to my team so we can continue to work on perfecting our broth and meat texture.  I hope we can serve you again in the near future.

I decided to try this place for the first time with a friend for lunch on a Sunday around 12:30 pm. We didn't have to wait since it wasn't busy. One thing that I noticed right off was the self order kiosk. It was super convenient to just walk in and order what you wanted without having any pressure. The menu on the kiosk provided pictures of the food and it made the ordering process fast and easy. I decided to order the vegetarian ramen and I was a little hesitant at first but it didn't disappoint me. The broth was super flavorful and it had a good amount of vegetables and noddles. They also provide soy sauce and gyro sauce along with a chili paste to add more flavor. I was satisfied with the overall taste, presentation portion, and service. I highly recommend this place to anyone who likes or is trying ramen for the first time. You won't regret it because your tummy will be happy.

I landed in Los Angeles and not even an hour later, I'm already hitting up a restaurant cos' I am just a hangry girl! This was the place I came across first because it was the closest ramen shop to the car rental place I was at. What do I order at a ramen shop? Not ramen of course. I got three dishes: a side of bamboo shoots, a cucumber salad with imitation crab meat and a Shiitake Enoki mushroom salad (Don't recall the proper name of the salad but I can't seem to find it on their website.) The salads were just meh but I don't blame them because this is a ramen place after all. I really like how they have a self serve kiosk where you can make your own order and then you sit down and they will bring you your food. I see this is very common in LA and very uncommon in NYC.The staff was friendly and the place is nice and bright and very welcoming. I like this place. I should try their ramen sometime.
Thank you for the review.  Hopefully you can come back to taste our ramen!

As my hunt continues for the best ramen out there - I have found quite a few worthy contenders. Silverlake does not fall into that category. The ramen here is okay - and the entirety of the experience gets merely a pass. The seating is awkward as you order and pay first then wait to be seated - What kind of service and quality of food am I tipping for, beforehand? The food wasn't very hot upon arrival which always uncomfortably settles. There's not much to write home about. Silverake is worth a try to determine for oneself what the rating is.

I have been meaning to visit the original location for some time, but guess what?! No need now. Silverlake Ramen recently expanded to a commercial shopping area near LB Airport off Lakewood (Hwy 19) and Carson. I typically avoid these types of centers, so I quit being a judgmental weenie and went for it.The menus are up front and you have to go to the right to see the cashier to order before sitting. I had the Cucumber Salad with crab and Shoyu on Fire. Their Shoyu Ramen is made with pork, chicken, or tofu in a clear chicken broth with shoyu, green onion, corn, seaweed, jalapeño, lime, and egg. I also added bamboo shoots. It was balanced and perfectly spiced at level 2. The staff is very friendly and attentive. They'll also being utilizing a self-service kiosk soon for

I also added bamboo shoots. It was balanced and perfectly spiced at level 2. The staff is very friendly and attentive. They'll also soon be utilizing a self-service kiosk for orders because you know it finna get mad crowded.

Solid Ramen in Long Beach! Yay! The Family all liked our bowls--I ordered the Blaze #2 spicy & I was sweatin' just a bit.  It was delicious. The broth is so creamy--creamier than I ever remember having before & I've had a lot of Ramen.  And I'm not hatin'. Just sayin'. I also love that chicken is a meat option. Welcome to the neighborhood Silverlake.

Went here during their grand opening last Monday and came 15 minutes before the yelp listed opening time...and they were already open. It seems like the team did it to accommodate the rush that they were expecting so props to them.As others have noted, you order up front and find a seat. I can't imagine how rough that is if you go to peak hours. But Silverlake Ramen (according to their website) seems to be in an aggressive growth stage so more locations are coming up possibly leading to shorter wait times.When places like Silverlake ramen open up, you do notice the tide of gentrification is rising in LB. I mention this because it's a bit pricy (ramen isn't usually cheap, but this place doesn't really have any "budget" options). The quality is there, but recognizing the status of where LB is and where it's heading is important too.I got the classic tonkotsu. The broth is very creamy and that's what Silverlake ramen is known for. The only other place I've been to with similarly creamy broth is Foo Foo Tei in Hacienda Heights/City of Industry. It was delicate level of creaminess that didn't feel overwhelming or too thick. I did add extra garlic to my ramen, but that's just me. The pork was melt-in-your-mouth soft, but they weren't very generous serving-wise. Like I said, there are very few bang for your buck ramen places because quality is key. This place, despite the restaurant's look and feel, is a little more on the high end.I'd skip the appetizers. A lot of them you can find at a mom and pop place in better quantities that taste just as good. But Silverlake ramen's ramen is worth the hype and definitely worth trying out.I saw the place tease an electronic register and a...pesto ramen. I'll be back because I'm curious, but I also really enjoy their broth.

We went the evening of the grand opening, and a lot of the four stars here are attributable to the great customer service which we received.  From the cashier, to the food expediter who checked in on us to apologize for the timing, and even to the check-ins after we got our meal, we definitely were made to feel attended to.As far as the actual food goes, the ramen is thoughtfully crafted, the spicy tonkotsu broth is complex in flavor, and the noodles appear to be housemade...but I found the chasu to be chewy, the bean sprouts limp, and the overall dish lacked a little zing that maybe some garlic or onion could have added.
Thank you for your review.  I will go over the review with my team as we are continuously working to improve our bowls.

I came here with 4 other friends on a Saturday night. It was moderately  busy, but there were some tables open outside (yes, there's  a heater). However, we decided to wait for a table inside and it only took about 10 minutes to be seated.I was helped by Samantha who alleviated a lot of indecisiveness for my meal. She was super patient  with me, despite me asking her a lot of questions about what to order and even made some funny remarks when answering my questions. She delivers great customer service and made me feel comfortable while speaking to her. I ended up going with her recommendation of the Classic Tonkotsu Ramen and was happy about my decision. Thanks, Samantha! :)
Not impressed. The pork slices were tough and too lean for my liking. Also, they rejected me when I asked for water to dilute my Tsukemen

Wow! I don't know why it's taken so long for me to try this place! My friends and I came around 6pm on a Sunday night and got seated pretty quickly. Service was amazing and our servers, Andy & Rumil, were so kind! Despite being quite busy, we were checked up on frequently and our water cups never went empty.I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with pork and it was rich and flavorful! I would definitely get this again.also lemme tell ya'll, that pork was THICC

I really don't see what the hype with the place is. We came soon after their soft opening so maybe they're working out the kinks, but there was a huge line to get in, not because the place was packed, but because you have to order from a host before you can sit. That process was very slow, and you looked inside and could clearly see the restaurant wasn't filled yet, so the line just gives an illusion of being full, seemed like hype-building to me. Looks like little kiosks will be used instead which will likely make the process more efficient. The food was ok, filling but I still think more expensive than it should've been. We both got the vegan ramen, the toppings really seemed random, didn't go that well together or with the broth. First we thought maybe just the vegan ramen is blah, and just an afterthought (to which I say, don't serve it if you're not gonna put effort into it), but my non-vegan coworker also said it's over-hyped. It's just ok, and service was nice, but really can't recommend.

I have been a bit skeptical about trying this place for awhile. A lot of my friends that have went there warned me of the terrible customer service so I've been purposely avoiding it. However, I was craving ramen recently since I had a cold so I decided to order the Classic Tonkotsu ramen for pick up. I made sure to order To-Go in order to prevent an interaction with rude employees -- but that didn't quite work out. On arrival, one of the employees, a tall Filipino(?) guy, walked up to the front without a single word to greet me. I was very sick and I had just got off work followed by school but I smiled and said hello and told him I was here for a pickup order. He looked incredibly annoyed like he wanted to shoot himself in the foot. Still no word spoken, he goes to the To-Go orders and asks if my name was Adam. I told him yes, he gives me the food, and says NOTHING else. He made it pretty obvious that he wanted me out as soon as possible and I was a nuisance to him.I exchanged less than 10 words with him and it made me never want to come back again. Usually I get over these interactions as I used to work in customer service for years, but it still annoys me thinking about it now. It's not hard to smile and be courteous; if it is, you're in the wrong job.If the ramen was worth it, maybe I would come back but it was honestly just okay. Not worth getting annoyed over so I don't think I'll ever come back here again. I should have listened to all the warnings I received about the poor customer service, would have saved me the headache.

This is my favorite ramen place in the Long Beach area. The pork is thick but it's so tender and flavorful. The broth is great and noodles are so good. Perfect for those cold California days. Their service is pretty fast and p The only downside is the place is pretty small. Not too many tables inside. A few table outside but I prefer indoors. Update: They usually include two slices of pork in the ramen but the last couple of times I ate here, they only put one slice of the pork. It's disappointing because it was a good portion. Why do they have to take something good away from their customers? Having second thoughts to eating here anymore.

This is my favorite ramen place in the Long Beach area. The pork is thick but it's so tender and flavorful. The broth is great and noodles are so good. Perfect for those cold California days. Their service is pretty fast and well. The only downside is the place is pretty small. Not too many tables inside. A few table outside but I prefer indoors.

This is one of my new favorite ramen spots and I am very picky about how I like my ramen!! I got the blaze tonkatsu and it was delicious. The broth is packed with flavor and I love the way the pork is cooked.  It is a little pricy compared to other ramen places, but the portion size is good.  I also ordered from here once on DoorDash, and they forgot to give me part of my order :( so I knocked a star off for that.

Long Beach has been beset by a ramen craze the past couple of years. I'm not the biggest fan of all the spots, but I still try them all as they open, just in case. We wandered into Silverlake Ramen with low expectations. The entry is a bit weird and I was distracted by the pesto ramen (what a strange idea). I almost ordered it, but I chose the classic ramen instead. I was happy about my decision when I saw another person eating it. I thought it would be more like pasta, but it looked very soupy and unappetizing. I didn't try it, however, so it might have been delicious.While waiting for our food, I started reading some of the negative reviews and commentary. We were slightly concerned, but when the ramen came, it was pretty good. The broth doesn't have the same depth as HiroNori's, but we were surprised by the flavor nonetheless. Let me just say that adding a dash of the tabletop chili enhances the taste tenfold, so you have to try it. Overall, this is now my second favorite ramen place in the neighborhood. Welcome!

Long overdue review! I came with my husband during soft opening. There was a line but we didn't end up waiting too long as there was seating available in the patio area. Upon entering the restaurant, you enter the line to order and there's a cool view of the open kitchen. The two of us shared the crispy chicken karaage, three kinds of mushrooms in butter, and tonkotsu ramen.Crispy Chicken Karaage: It has a good chicken to batter ratio and the flavor was there, but unfortunately it wasn't crispy.Three Kinds of Mushrooms in Butter: Very simple dish with three types of mushrooms in a butter sauce, with some salad on the side. Tonkotsu Ramen: Noodles were chewy, the soup was flavorful and rich, and it didn't leave me feeling super bloated. (Tonkotsu is usually really heavy for me.) The meat was a bit lean; I think I would've enjoyed it more if it was a bit fattier. Service was okay. No bad notes about the service, but also nothing memorable about the service. Not sure that I'd wait longer than maybe 30 min for this, but it was worth trying!

Love the atmosphere of this place. Nice interior, very modern, and honestly you can't go wrong with ramen. I got the tsukemen dipping ramen and I loved every bite. We got the pork belly buns and loved the juiciness of every bite. Definitely have to come back to try different appetizers and other ramen dishes. Service was great! Parking is easy since there's a lot.  There's outside seating and inside. Amazing food and service will definitely be back.

Happy that another solid ramen spot has been added to Long Beach! Heard a lot of great things about Silverlake Ramen and it definitely lives up to the hype! I ordered the Blaze Tonkatsu in Medium Spice. Great flavor and huge portion! I could definitely go for more spice the next time I visit. Excellent customer service. Good amount of seating options and lots of parking. Will definitely be back!

Good ramen taste wise but there were a few things that were off putting to me. Our table didn't have spoons and the tofu in my soup was ice cold. The service was nonexistent. It was my first time to this place so I wanted to know if the chili at the table was super spicy. But I couldn't find anyone to ask.

I have been able to try this place out a week ago. I think this place is a great addition to the Long Beach food scene. I am not a ramen guru, but I do know what I like. The place was moderately crowded but the flow of service was good. There have been previous complaints on long wait time and poor service, but I feel that new restaurants should be given a chance to improve and make changes. But the more important part is how the food taste. They have a few other items besides ramen. But ramen is what you come for. The tonkatsu ramen is where it's at. Very flavorful broth and noodles were on point. I love the black garlic oil that comes with the ramen. Pork buns were also very nice. I never tried the original location so I can't say how close it is in flavor to the original. I suggest given this place a try. You won't be disappointed.

I came to this location with a friend and we thought the place was pretty good. I had the Veggie Ramen and my friend got the Spicy Miso Ramen. The broth and the veggies were pretty good on my end. I love the broccoli and mushroom based broth. The noodles were okay though. They were a tad bit under cooked but the broth and veggie combo made up for it nevertheless. I truly adored the aesthetics of the restaurant. I love how open and modern the space was. It was truly inviting. Also, the customer service was excellent. They were speedy and present when attending to my friend and I's needs. Overall, I think Silverlake Ramen is a lovely addition to the Long Beach Exchange. I think that with better attention to the noodles and broth, Silverlake Ramen could have the potential in being one of the greats (in terms of ramen) here in SoCal.

I do not yelp much. Maybe I am hungry and little grumpy.Not a big fan of the prepay idea. Forces your customer to be less likely leave, when the food takes too long.*order a large meal, cause I was particularly hungry today..Update: talked to employees. They seem really nice and sincere. But stomach is growling...2nd update: staff came back and was really nice. They comp my food. Feel bad about posting this. Must have been hangry.

Was doing work in the area and stopped in for lunch. Maybe I came on a bad day?This is obviously a straight take out place by the airport, which is cool as long as the food is good...Chashu was mediocre at best, noodles under done, the broth, which came separately from the ingredients, was no only cold, but left a weird residue on the plate. Like the mixture they used didn't dissolve long enough. I guess you can certainly do worse then this place but with so many great ramen places in the area, I won't be coming back.

UPDATED REVIEW: 10/24/192nd visit to Silverlake Ramen, ordered the Blaze level 2 spicy which was very enjoyable but if you want extra noodles as is common at most ramen places, be prepared to wait almost 10 mins for it. This demonstrated how ordering up front, then sit-down second system is very flawed. We had one server tell us he could take care of it and another server tell us we had to wait in line again, but ultimately they just took our card and swiped it for the extra noodle order. Not uncommon to decide you want extra food as you're eating, and didn't want to wait back in ordering line.However, there was very little follow-up and we had to repeatedly ask where our extra noodle order was and by then our broth was cold and not as enjoyable. Table service is not their strength as evidenced by little follow-up, so paying in advance including pre-paying for tip/table service, do at your own discretion. You order, then they bring you the food and drinks. But don't expect much after that in terms of actual table "service". Makes for a completely different dining experience. But the staff seemed more than ready to clean up our table and clear our plates when we appeared finished eating. Cleanliness was good, service needs improvement.Just wanted to give others fair warning about this, that although the food is tasty, service can greatly affect your dining experience. Past the soft opening stages, with room for improvement. The chicken karaage bowl was delicious with generous portion sizes, and was served with some kind of aoli sauce on top. (Not your traditional karaage) Also, the pork served with the ramen bowl is not what I remember from when I visited the original location. I distinctly remember pork meat that was tender, flavorful but also served with some skin-on, deep fried and crunchy. (Almost like lechon) This is what made it unique and stand out from other pork ramen bowls. Craving this but I realize not all locations are created equal. Hoping that the LB location would be able to come close to it.The pork served here is a large piece but definitely on the fatty side with little edible meat. Perhaps it just adds flavor to the broth by soaking in it? I just didn't finish eating it.As for dessert or ordering any other food, we opted against it based on the inconvenience of ordering more as went. Missed opportunity, but wonder if any one else has had similar experiences.

Got here for soft opening today 9/26 at 5pm. Casual atmosphere, ordered at cashier up front, then self-seating with options to sit at the bar, tables inside or outdoor patio. Kaarage chicken is a solid appetizer, crispy outside yet still juicy on the inside with a hint of ginger. We also tried the 3 kinds of mushroom with butter (with salad) which was different and worth trying. Classic tonkotsu ramen is the standard for me, pork broth with black garlic oil and slightly creamy, without being too salty. Overall, I enjoyed the flavor. This was a good balance as I'm usually not a fan of overly creamy ramen broth, and this was done much better than a certain other ramen place in LB. The order came with pork (or choice of chicken or tofu) green onions, soft boiled egg, spinach, seaweed and bean sprouts. Those who like spicy would enjoy The Blaze, or Spicy Tonkotsu option.  Extra noodles are available to order too.Grand opening Monday 9/30 at 11am! Plenty of parking at LB exchange. Believe they are also having another soft opening tomorrow 9/27.Checked their website which says more locations to open in Cerritos, Huntington Beach and Costa Mesa. Really glad more good eats are popping up in the LBC! Keep 'em coming.

Always satisfied when we come here! We usually order The Classic (with Tofu added), The Blaze, and Chicken Karaage. All this for a little under $40 (with tip added). We love all the flavors in both ramen bowls especially the broth! The pork belly is thick, flavorful, soft, and juicy! The portions are very filling as well! Our new favorite place to go!
Delicious ramen, really enjoy the pork its very juicy. Very consistent service every time.
Hi Lisette!  Glad we’re able to provide you great food and service during this time.  Thank you and take care!

My husband and I came across this location while checking out the new LBX center. It just so happened that it was their first day of soft opening!! The line moved pretty quick and everyone seemed just so excited and happy that the store was finally opened. Great and simple menu. The decor is classic modern with very comfortable furniture and a solid patio. Mixture of warm wood, stainless, dark floors, clean finishes. Also there is a huge hand drawn mural on the wall. I ordered the Tonkotsu with pork and my husband the shoyu on fire. We also got the karaage which is their fried chicken appetizer.  Wow the food was amazing and the broth for the tonkotsu was perfectly rich and creamy. Shoyu was clean and "refreshing" if that makes sense. The food took a bit to come out, but it's totally understandable as it was their first day and obviously the crew needs to get the hang of things. It was awesome to see everyone in the back working hard, talking to each other, working hard. Overall, for anyone reading this post, be patient with the speed of the ramen as it takes time to create that masterpiece. Everything will be ok. Enjoy this new addition to LBX and the city of LB.

I go back to my first memories of Silverlake Ramen and read my review then. And sadly, I have to report this new experience was underwhelmingly mediocre. At the entrance forms a queue, get to the register and order. They'll give you a number and you'll go find a seat. When we realized no tables were open we stood looking around, making eye contact with some of the staff but no "hop to it" action until I stopped one of them on their tracks to ask. But a table opened up because the people sitting at the table of 4 was just waiting for his to-go order. So he and his son got up, allowing us to take the table.Anyways, I missed the crispiness of the pork belly as I so fondly remember. I had the Shoyu - it was good, but nothing special. A simple bowl of ramen. Thin noodles, not my usual favorite, but chewy. Broth was a bit oily but flavorful. The boys had the Tsukemen and had the same thoughts. Wasn't the "best Tsukemen I've ever had" experience he remembered. It's nice to have them in the area. Unfortunately, it's not going to be our to-go.

ALRIGHT! The wait is finally over, here at LBX! Got in here on their soft opening today 9/26 [Grand Opening Monday 9/30] Okay, enough talk, let's get to the FOOD! So I started with their Pork Bun (marinated pork belly,  pickled onions, aioli, green onion) and guess what?! it was BOMB! Then of course I got the ramen! So I had The Classic tonkotsu -- that broth was so rich! And say no more, all you have to do, is try it!

So I decided to follow my heart and I was not disappointed. Although it might be on the pricier side and the wait is a bit long, it was well deserved because the food was solid. I thought the atmosphere and their shirts were pretty cool, I defintely need a bunch of those ASAP! Best of all, that Steven guy and the rest of the team were very accomodating and helpful with everyone despite it still being a soft opening.But the real mvp was the chashu, I could literally eat it by itself. Great place for families and parking is abundant in the back. Plus, the cool part is I can burn some calories by walking over to tastea for some milk tea! Overall, awesome ramen joint.

When I walked up and saw the line I was hesitant if I wanted to wait. Even as I waited in line the staff were very nice and answered questions. The place isn't very big so expect a wait to get a seat. The staff hustle but be mindful they just opened so things aren't perfect. So why am I giving them five stars if they aren't perfect yet. 1. The food was amazing 2. The Staff was attentive and responsive3. If mistakes were made the staff not only apologized but went out of their way to make each guest happy. If the goof was a major one they gave a nice discount or comped people's meal. (Don't try to get over on them, I can tell they really want to have gold star service) 4. The chefs personally check in with customers and not just if there is a complaints. 5. Tell value your business and show it In a few weeks this place will be a well oiled machine. So don't sleep on it. The ramen is damn near on par with the Torrance area (true ramen aficionados will know what's up. )The only tiny note I have is that the chatsu (pork) isn't as tender as it needs to be, however even with that it was flavorful.

I was excited to try this place after hearing such good recommendations from friends and family on the LA location. It is located in the Hangar with plenty of parking and a good amount of seating. The space is clean and inviting with lots of windows for great natural light. This is an order and seat yourself establishment so service isn't a big factor but I did order and receive my food very quickly. Price is about average for ramen in this area.I had the spicy tonkotsu ramen with pork (chashu). The broth was light and subtle in flavor but was a good consistency. Noodles were firm and on the thicker side. The pork was very okay - thick and fatty but unable to soak up the broth as much as I'd like. Overall, it was very okay. It wouldn't be my first choice in ramen but I wouldn't say no to coming here again.

I usually don't write reviews right away but after reading all the bad reviews, I feel compelled to leave my review from yesterday to serve them justice (as it seems like the owner really takes the time to read the reviews and really make improvements accordingly). So we came here for lunch yesterday (Saturday 10/19). We came right before they opened at 11AM and to my surprise, there were already people waiting outside. We were seated quickly and the order process was easy breezy (you order first and get seated later). We ordered the classic and spicy TONKOTSU ramens, pork bun, chicken karaage.. and beer. While the bun and chicken karaage were okay for me, I loved their classic tonkotsu- it was not bland, not too oily, and the portion was big that all of us had to take ours to go lol. Great service and nice vibe! I'm really happy that there's another good ramen place in LB. Please keep up the good work and I hope you guys will get better and better!

Good mirror to take bathroom selfies in 5/5But seriously, one of the best broths I've had in a while. Not too salty or creamy, but enough flavor to give you a kick. I do wish my ramen was firmer, need to see if they have that option available next time I go.

So I've been waiting for this place to open for at least the past three months. Super excited to have another ramen spot close by but I was a little let down.The service was quick considering reading the other reviews. But the food was meh. The broth was almost cold and the noodles were soggy. On top of that the pork was so thiiiicccckk that I couldn't enjoy it. But the egg was AMAZING! Perfect soy egg with the most perfect middle. Also got the chicken and it was ok but the sauce was really good.

Yummy place! Good ramen in LB when I can't go to my ultimate ramen place Tatsu ramen in West Hollywood. This place is busy! You have to time it right if you want to be sat right away. If not no worries, they try and move  fast! I got a Spicy Tonkotsu ramen and it warmed me up. It had flavor and did not need anything  by added. Service- waiter forgot our waters, forks and napkins. Maybe we asked for too much?

Tried out a new ramen place in the area and probably won't be back. Came with my best friend and we waited 30 minutes for 2 bowls of ramen and a small chicken karaage order. The original tonkotsu ramen was decent 8/10 but the spicy tonkotsu was 3/10. Chicken karaage didn't taste that great 4/10. They were just fried pieces of chicken cut small not like traditional Japanese tasty karaage and they needed to work on the dipping sauce. No bueno. My best friend was unlucky and got a raw piece of chicken ...I would just go to HiroNori on Carson in Long Beach or Kitakata in Buena Park.

A big bowl of ramen tastes damn good from the comfort of your booth on a rainy day.  The food here is amazing I got The Blaze and the Fried Gyoza.Tonkotsu Spicy Ramen (The Blaze) is a deeply flavored broth with enough spice to warm the stomach. Go with the pork belly (other options are chicken and tofu), with chunks damn near the size of a standard pork chop!Fried Gyoza these pork dumplings have the perfect crunch, the flavor, and the sauce to make them a must-order.

Silverlake Ramen is freaking solid.I am a ramen snob. I am a bit picky about the broth and the noodles. I've been to a lot of ramen places in Orange and Los Angeles county and it's actually pretty hard to find legit ramen. Thankfully, Silverlake Ramen is legitWalked in during lunch time, ordered at the counter, took my number and sat at their community table. Yes, the line was long to order, but the place was PACKED so basically just waiting for people to finish their meals. Basically same concept as writing your name down and waiting for a table like their original restaraunt in LA. I started off with gyoza and they were very tasty with the perfect level of fried. I looked up and saw the chef in the back hand making their dumplings! I usually only get their blaze ramen because, well, it's the best. Today I thought I'd try their shoyu ramen, and it was delicious. It has a more clean and light taste than the tonkotsu style. Thank Jesus I work 10 minutes away so I think I'll be here pretty often.

New ramen place in the area! Hoorayyyyy! My partner and I were originally going to try the Silverlake Ramen closer to Los Angeles because I had just landed in LAX, but I found this location closer to home when I Yelped. Note: by the time we arrived at Silverlake Ramen it was 9:20ish - a pretty late dinner for me, so I didn't want to order anything heavy. Once you enter the restaurant, there's a line to the right where you put in your order and pay first. There's two kiosks available (pretty neat and first time seeing one at a ramen place!) and a cashier as well, but unfortunately, when we went, they were experiencing some technical difficulties with their kiosk systems and with their cash register as well - something related to credit cards. It took at least 10 mins for the cashier to ring up the group of two in front of us. During this time, I tried using the kiosks, but that didn't work out, so it took around 15-20 mins in total before we were able to get our order in. I know this is totally not anyone's fault and it's most likely out of their control, but it was still a little off putting, so I took off 1 Star for that as it's still part of the whole experience. Maybe the kiosks is new and they haven't fully gotten the hang of it yet. I don't know what the issue was, but I do have to give credit to all the staff for being professional and aiding us through the process.We both ordered the vegetarian ramen. It came with avocado surprisingly (a first for me), but that adds a slight creaminess to the broth. The miso broth is rich in flavor - light and fragrant! The tofu and kale is more mild, but with the broth, it balances out really well. My favorite ingredients has to be the brocollini and mushrooms! Those were so yummy. And last but not least, even though we don't get to adjust the firmness of the noodles, these were chewy - just how I like it! Big portions and was so satisfied by the end of it. Would totally recommend and I'd like to come back again sometime. Hopefully by then, their kiosks would be running without any hiccups!

This place had its grand opening roughly a week ago and my party waited for roughly 30 minutes before we placed our order with the cashier. We then picked up a number and chose a table to sit. We ordered the Three kinds of mushroom with butter, The Classic, and The Shoyu.Three kinds of mushroom with butter: As the name suggested, it came with eringi, shiitake, and enoki mushrooms. The dish also came with mixed spring salad which added an extra layer of texture with the sautéed mushrooms. It was a good balance between savory and light saltiness.The Classic: We chose pork as the protein and the creamy pork broth was very rich. The pork and the broth complemented each other well. It was a good sized portion of ramen and everything is fresh. Ramen was a good texture and one should definitely not wait to eat them because the noodles can suck up the broth very quickly.The Shoyu: We chose chicken as the protein to try out the different proteins they offer and the chicken was surprisingly juicy. The broth was made with chicken broth with shoyu--I found that it was refreshing compared to the heavier broth of The Classic.We did encounter a minor hiccup when The Classic took slightly longer (~30 minutes after The Shoyu arrived) to be served. We had to check in with one of the waiters and inquire what had happened with the order. The store manager, Steven, apologized profusely and made sure the order got to us quickly. He also ensure we left happy and got us the Crispy Chicken Karaage on the house. (Thank you, Steven!) So we have an added review on this appetizer!Crispy Chicken Karaage (small): The chicken was crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. It came with a slice of lemon and the spicy aioli sauce. Personally, I enjoyed the lemon juice way more than the sauce. We both felt that the sauce was overpowering the taste of the fried chicken. If you do get the appetizer, feel free to try both for yourself ;)It was a good experience overall--I look forward to coming back again in the near future and try out their other ramens!

Delicious delicious ramen! The ordering process for a sit down restaurant is a little different. You actually order and pay for your food when you first walk in and then you are seated. Started off well with both. The gyoza was perfectly crisp and juicy and you can never go wrong with the crispy rice w/ spicy tuna. I liked that it wasn't overly drenched in sauce, but there's enough on the plate to get some more if you'd like. I got The Blaze (spicy tonkotsu) w/ corn added on. I always get mild spice to be on the safe side, but they have self-serve chili paste on the tables to kick it up a notch as you please. It really wasn't that spicy so I'm sure I'll get the medium next time. It came out piping hot and the egg was cooked to perfection. The broth was very flavorful, creamy, not too salty or bland. It paired perfectly with their crisp ice cold beer topped with special foam.Overall, good portions, good service, and we all left satisfied! I had always wanted to try the one in Silverlake, but never got around to it so I'm glad this location opened! Definitely will be coming back :)

Tried Silverlake Ramen (SLR) in Long Beach about two weeks ago. It's a very attractive, modernist ramen restaurant located in a newly renovated food and entertainment gathering area of Long Beach, near the airport. It was a cold evening. We were seated near a side door which opened to the patio seating area. As the wait staff and customers came and went out to the patio, the door would swing open, followed by cold air which would blast onto our table. The room was loud due to normal customer noise, not loud music. The waiter arrived and immediately informed us they are out of chicken for the evening -- at 6:30 p.m. for G0D's sake. My now vegetarian ramen was supposed to be spicy. It was indeed spicy, so much so the dish was burning rather than tasty. I am used to and enjoy spicy food, but there is a difference between simply burning hot spicy food versus the judicious use of "hot" spices to make a tasty, yet spicy dish. This was spicy hot, just to be spicy hot -- uncomfortably so, I might add -- not tasty. I sent it back. The others at my table liked but not "loved" their ramen.  Here is my suggestions: 1. Install sound baffling devices to reduce ambient noise. 2. Install a second door corridor or a heat blowing device to create a barrier of sorts between the patio and the first table at the doorway.  Perhaps not seat anyone near the patio door when it is cold outside. 3. Be sure to order enough chicken to make it through the night considering your business is based on selling chicken-based ramen in addition to pork. 4. Improve the taste of your product, you have a lot of competition for business, you need to be on your game to provide an equal or better product. SLR failed in that regard. Do better, improve, its not too late.  I would give the place one more try, they may have had an "off night." But, as it stands, SLR is as average as one could get for ramen in So Cal...sorry but that's my story folks.

This shit was delicious. Very silky and creamy . I normally can't fit that much in my stomach but it was so good I almost finished it . Yum

First time at this place and I loved it! I had the pork ramen and it was delicious. Great addition to the Long Beach Exchange!

Great atmosphere and perfect location but most importantly great tasting food and exceptional service. From the moment I walked in I was greeted with warm and friendly smiles. I highly recommend this place if you want great food and service.

Got the blaze tonkatsu ramen and spicy tuna. This place has potential but my boiled egg was cold and the tonkatsu was room temperature, and didn't have the best texture or flavor. I was super excited to have Silverlake Ramen come to LBX but that quickly faded after eating here. First, the layout is off. Whoever designed this location did not know what they were doing. Ok. So, you are a new location and you have a handwritten sign to tell your customers how to order? What? Literally every other business in the area has this part down. Best part, all the menus are on the tiny hostess desk, and you cannot get to a menu if ANY other customer is ordering. That's just stupid. There are several white menu boards on the wall, so I assume the young girl that took our order will be out of a job once they get the computer ordering up and going. Food...food was blah. Tonkatsu is usually delicious and full of that rich bone marrow taste. This broth, not so much. This tasted bland and thin. It was like the broth was thinned out with milk or something. I ordered the Blaze Hot, level 3, their hottest...it wasn't hot. I made the mistake of ordering chicken as my protein. Bad, bad mistake. The chicken should not have been served. The breast had woody breast, a condition that happens when chickens are put to slaughter too quickly and raised to get too large. The meat has the texture of uncooked meat but is cooked. It tastes rubbery and off. So, long story, passed on the chicken. Thank goodness I ordered extra egg. The egg was delicious and cooked perfectly. Last, the noodles. The noodles were a mess. Basically, a thick blob of stuck together noodles. Sorry to say, I will not be coming back. There are too many delicious ramen places within 30 minutes to come back. There is no excuse for serving inedible chicken. If you put ramen in your name, I expect a lot. Unfortunately, Silverlake Ramen fell short

It was my first time trying this spot out. It was recommended to me by my parents. It's a small nice spot to eat at in Long Beach. I ordered the blaze and it was good. I will come back to try other options

Had a bowl of The Blaze spicy tonkotsu ramen. Before mixing in the spice I tried the broth and it was tasty, the added spice hit the spot for me. Not crazy hot but hot enough to enjoy the flavor and heat. Pork was fine but I have a preference for a more tender preparation.

Not the best ramen I've had.. I went to the Long Beach location due to the hype I've been hearing about this place. I think it's just because "silverlake" is in the name.. lol There's better ramen spots.

Been here twice now and it's been good. First time was ok. I had the tsukumen (dipping ramen)with chicken. The noodles were thick and chewy and the dipping broth full of flavor (pork and fish base). The chicken I had with it was just boiled chicken so nothing special but with the dipping broth delicious. Also tried the spicy ramen, which was the original just made spicy (pork based broth). The 2 slices of pork that comes with the ramen is pretty thick. The ramen is the thinner noodle which was a I felt was a little over done. Second time was better. I had the original, which I think actually tastes better than the spicy version and swapped out the ramen for the tsukumen noodle. You can taste the depth of flavor in the broth and not just the spice. If you want spice you can always add some at the table. The noodle also had a nice chew to itAlso had the shoyu ramen which is a little eh...(chicken base broth).

Always on the lookout for great ramen places. Took a chance on this place as I saw a long line waiting to order. I soon realized that the long line & wait time was due to the host/cashier walking away to chat with co-workers, drink water, or stand in the kitchen after every single person who ordered. This may have been on purpose to give the kitchen time to prepare or deal with a rush, but the tables weren't even full; this just looks horribly wrong to waiting customers. The food was just ok, so it was not worth the wait. Sadly disappointed.

A MUST GO!!! From the moment I walked in the staff was very nice and kept me informed on how to order as it was my first time. I ordered the Tsukemen and my friend ordered The Blaze ramen. BOTH WERE AMAZINGGG! The vibe and atmosphere was absolutely great and the bathrooms smelled amazing(some thing I never say about other restaurants). Great music too! Will definitely come back

Was waiting for this place to open. You order when you walk in then sit down anywhere there is an open table. I order the blaze, wow it was good. Noodles were soft and broth was very tasty. There are side condiments on that table if you want to add more spice to your broth which I love. Very filling. Definitely will be back. Finally a good ramen close by.

Phenomenal ramen, coming from a person who is very selective with his ramen!  Having gone to the original location, I was glad to hear they opened up a location that was closer to my job site.  It's a perfect place to bring friends if you're craving ramen.  Definitely swing by if you're in the LB area for this well-known establishment!

This place opened up not too long ago and I'm glad it did as there's a new ramen place that's close to home! I went in and tried the Blaze ramen bowl with pork and I was satisfied with it! I loved the rich, porky, spicy broth and the texture of the noodles as it had a nice bite to it! I loved the casual vibe the place had as I felt that anyone and everyone could eat here and enjoy a bowl of quality ramen. I appreciated the cleanliness of the establishment and the attitudes of the entire staff including the kitchen! I will definitely be coming back here and trying their other ramen bowls and rice bowls as I have high hopes and expectations for them!

This location is perfect! Everyone that works here is super friendly! Location is super clean and the food is to die for!

Clean and with a courteous staff this Silverlake restaurant is good to dine in for a quickie. Their broth has a light creamy flavor that goes well with the meal. So excited to see a variety of food options @LBX. My husband and I went during their soft opening (Sunday afternoon). Everyone was very nice and friendly. Plain and simple - it ain't good. Very disappointed in this knock-off ramen that's wasting valuable real estate in Long Beach.

I am providing this review since there are correctable issues.  We enjoy ramen immensely and it is in our interest to have  good ramen restaurants in our area.  So I decided to take the time to offer this review.It was our first time at Silverlake and my son ordered Tonkotsu Ramen and I ordered Shoyu Ramen.  My Shoyu ramen was barely warm.  The egg yolk was cold as was pork belly steak.  I went today because I had a craving but it was not at all satisfying.  No part of a bowl of ramen, whether it is the soup, vegetable, eggs, meat or even the bowl, should be served cold.  This is just amateurish.  The noodle was a bit stiff for my taste but I'll chalk it up as their style.  Aside from the temperature, I really didn't enjoy the 1/2" thick grilled pork belly steak.  Shoyu ramen is a rather delicate  dish and the half-warmed stiff pork belly sitting in a lukewarm soup just did not do it for me.  I'd much prefer thin slices of chashu.My son did enjoy his tonkotsu ramen, though it was too spicy to savor the subtleties, if there were any.  On a separate note, there were no seating that I would have found to be a good table.  Each was either by the door, major aisle, or the restroom.  The two stars are for friendly staff and prompt service.All in all, it feels like the operators missed the opportunity to establish a good eatery in a popular new commercial development.

The ramen was great when the wife and I tried it a month ago. Unfortunately, tonight the cuts of meat in our ramens were terrible: mostly fat and quite small. There's a lot of potential here so hopefully their quality stabilizes.

My husband and I were looking forward to this after hearing good things, and since I had a sudden craving for gyoza, figured why not. TL:DR version -Recommendations for improvement: seating system, carry all menu items, keep utensils and napkin containers full, faster service.Positives: I am a positive person and I can't think of anything! MAJOR SAD FACE.Full version:Walked in and wasn't really sure where to go, we saw the line to the right and followed the line. Ordered at the kiosk, that was pretty cool, except they were sold out of gyoza. Ugh. We scanned through the menu, and there were actually a lot of items sold out, including their green tea (that's all I remember), but that was a bummer. We ordered chicken karaage, tonkatsu ramen, shoyu on fire. You pay everything up front at the kiosk or with the cashier, including tip. We're all paid up and tipped and sitting by 4:57pm.We sit at the table right behind the cashier, wait, five mins later or so, our chicken karaage arrives... there aren't any napkins in the utensil container on my table, so I get up and get it myself from the communal table... no big deal, we're happy... for now.They have a seating system where they match the ticket number to a table number in their system. There's no table number that you get, no buzzer, food just shows up. The problem with that is that the customer doesn't exactly know that, so it seems like we can move tables if there's a better option. I heard at least four conversations between the cashier and the server not finding the tables, and even a disagreement between the cashier and a server, with the cashier stating to a server "well if they move what do you want me to do about it?", in a very non-teamwork kind of tone. Not something I want to hear as a customer, especially since I'm sitting less than a foot away from the cashier (move that table or add a partition please), so I told the server "hey, those customers moved to that table over there". But yeah... at least four parties that came in after us moved, and I knew exactly where they moved to because I was waiting for FORTY+ minutes for my food. Not a single server came until I was finally able to flag them down after about TWENTY FIVE mins after the karaage came. And all those people that came in after us that moved, they all got their food before we got ours.If I didn't have to pay up front, and tip these people, I would've just walked out of there. But with the already super long wait, and not wanting to deal with getting a refund and having that be super slow and getting more irritated, we waited. Food arrives at 5:38 FINAL-FREAKIN-LY, and again, I had to get up cuz this time there weren't any soup spoons. Like seriously, I got here before the dinner rush, doesn't anyone check inventory? F***. The food portion was big. Lots of meat, which was nice to see. The pork belly in mine was thick... that's usually not a problem, but if you're going to have thick cuts, at least cook it until it's tender. Mine was tough, and I would've rather had thinner slices. Sure, portion was huge - for $12.50/bowl, it should be. What a mediocre experience. Silverlake Ramen should've just stayed in Silverlake.

In Raman heavy Long Beach this is still a great addition.  The chicken Soup style ramen is unlike any I've had before, broth is rich and delicious and the noodles perfectly firm.  The outdoor dining is pleasant on a warm afternoon. Have beef twice and will be going back soon.

Had very high expectations when trying this place out. We have tried many ramen spots in the past and were hoping to add this to our list of favorites. Unfortunately, this was not the case. Their line was out the door, you had to wait and order at the register before sitting down at a table. Kind of an odd way of doing things, but maybe it was supposed to make the dining experience easier? I am not entirely sure, so we ordered the tonkotsu ramen and a couple of beers. I kindly asked the cashier if we were able to order more beers after we sat at the table. He politely said no, and stated we would have to wait in the line to order another drink. That was unfortunate, but we still had a positive attitude and couldn't wait to try the ramen. While eating the ramen, the chashu pork was cut into huge slices and was extremely chewy. It grossed us out so much, that we pushed the meat to the side and finished the noodles and broth, which were delicious! May give this place another try in the future, but not likely.

Pretty disappointed, I was really looking forward to the iconic thick cuts of tender pork that the original Silverlake ramen consistently provided. Good food. Not a huge fan of the chashu, but the blaze ramen itself was tasty. The spicy tuna with crispy rice was really good.
